comments:
This course surveys the phylogeny and anatomy of vertebrate organisms from a comparative evolutionary perspective. The lecture will concentrate on the history, diversity, structure and function of vertebrates. Students registering for BIOL 330 section 001 must also register for BIOL 336 section 101, the lab portion of the course. Students wishing to take only the lecture (section 002) must contact the Biology department for permission.

Students thought the subject material was "interesting," "not difficult to understand," and useful for medical school. Others thought the information was "pretty irrelevant unless you want to be a paleontologist."

Dr. Dunham was "very willing to discuss course material" in and outside of class, and he was frank about the information that would be on the exam. However, one student found that he discussed much more material than what was necessary for the exams. Also, sometimes he "glosse[d] over” the material that was on the exams, or didn’t put all of it on the slides. 

Students recommend this class to any "biology/pre-med major." Exams are "extremely difficult" and "require a lot of memorization" but are "graded fairly." Purchasing the optional textbook is recommended.
